articles.description:
Posted by Oliver Chang, OSS-Fuzz team 
Since launching in 2016, Google's free OSS-Fuzz code testing service has helped get over 8800 vulnerabilities and 28,000 bugs fixed across 850 projects. Today, we‚Äôre happy to announce an expansion of our OSS-Fuzz Rewards Program, plus new features in OSS-Fuzz and our involvement in supporting academic fuzzing research. 
Refreshed OSS-Fuzz rewards 
  
The OSS-Fuzz project's purpose is to support the open source community in adopting fuzz testing, or fuzzing ‚Äî an automated code testing technique for uncovering bugs in software. In addition to the OSS-Fuzz service, which provides a free platform for continuous fuzzing to critical open source projects, we established an OSS-Fuzz Reward Program in 2017 as part of our wider Patch Rewards Program. 
We‚Äôve ope‚Ä¶
articles.title: Taking the next step: OSS-Fuzz in 2023

The Chrome Security Team prioritizes the security and privacy of Chrome‚Äôs users, and we are unwilling to compromise on these values.  
Google includes or removes CA certificates within the Chrome Root Store as it deems appropriate for user safety in accordance with our policies. The selection and ongoing inclusion of CA certificates is done to enhance the security of Chrome and promote interoperability.  
Behavior that attempts to degrade or subvert security and privacy on the web is incomp‚Ä¶

articles.description:
Posted by Dana Jansens (she/her), Chrome Security Team  
We are pleased to announce that moving forward, the Chromium project is going to support the use of third-party Rust libraries from C++ in Chromium. To do so, we are now actively pursuing adding a production Rust toolchain to our build system. This will enable us to include Rust code in the Chrome binary within the next year. We‚Äôre starting slow and setting clear expectations on what libraries we will consider once we‚Äôre ready. 
In this blog post, we will discuss how we arrived at the decision to support third-party Rust libraries at this time, and not broader usage of Rust in Chromium. 
Why We Chose to Bring Rust into Chromium
Our goal in bringing Rust into Chromium is to provide a simpler (no IPC) and safer (less complex C++ overal‚Ä¶

articles.description:
This short piece by Jim Nielsen resonated with me (much like Manu‚Äôs post resonated with Jim). He says:
I like this idea of beginning to notice and bring attention to people or creative works that intentionally bring closure, even when you‚Äôre left wanting a little more.
When it comes to open source software, people often see a lack of activity and proclaim that a project is unmaintained. Sometimes that‚Äôs true, but sometimes the project is merely finished, and that‚Äôs okay. In fact, it‚Äôs better than okay. It‚Äôs downright successful.
There‚Äôs a big difference between quitting and finishing. Quitting is in the realm of failure, but finishing is in the realm of success. The key is to define what finished means before you get there, lest you feel like you‚Äôre merely quitting.
The art of knowing when to quit? Sure. But how about the art of knowing how to finish?
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: The art of knowing when to quit

Discovery is one of the more challenging facets of federated social networking. It gets even more challenging now that Twitter‚Äôs API is getting paywall‚Äôd, so most of the free tools to port your Twitter social graph over to Mastodon will quit working. I expect more tools like StreetPass to pop up in the coming days as the Fediverse seems to be capturing that hacker spirit Twitter once embraced.

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
What‚Äôs old is new cool again. Here‚Äôs Andy Jiang, writing on Deno‚Äôs blog:
In the past 10 years, the median size for a desktop webpage has gone from 468 KB to 2284 KB, a 388.3% increase. For mobile, this jump is even more staggering ‚Äî 145 KB to 2010 KB ‚Äî a whopping 1288.1% increase.
That‚Äôs a lot of weight to ship over a network, especially for mobile. As a result, users experience terrible UX, slow loading times, and a lack of interactivity until everything is rendered. But all that code is necessary to make our sites work the way we want.
This is the problem with being a frontend dev today. What started out fun for frontend developers, building shit-hot sites with all the bells and whistles, has kinda turned into not fun. We‚Äôre now fighting different browsers to support, slow networks to ship code over, and intermittent, mobile connections. Supporting all these permutations is a giant headache.
How do we square this circle? By heading back to the server (Swiss basement not required).
He goes on to talk about isomorphic JavaScript frameworks and Deno‚Äôs offerings in this space. But hey, you don‚Äôt need all that fancy stuff to do SSR. All you need is a programming language that can render HTML (this is almost all languages) and a server‚Ä¶
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: The future (and the past) of the web is server-side rendering

Filippo Valsorda:
Last May I left my job on the Go team at Google to experiment with more sustainable paths for open-source maintainers. I held on to my various maintainer hats (Go cryptography, transparency tooling, age, mkcert, yubikey-agent‚Ä¶), iterated on the model since September, and I‚Äôm happy to report that I am now a full-time independent open-source maintainer.
People like Filippo are still (unfortunately) the exception, not the rule. BUT! I‚Äôll celebrate every time an open source maintainer makes it to the promised land, hopefully paving the way for others to follow after.
I‚Äôm sharing details about my progress to hopefully popularize the model, and eventually help other maintainers adopt it, although I‚Äôm not quite ready to recommend anyone else drop everything to try this just yet.

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
Bryan Braun reflects on years of pairing:
I‚Äôve pair-programmed in a lot of different situations. I‚Äôve been the junior developer who needed to be unblocked. I‚Äôve been the new team member, being onboarded to a new codebase. I‚Äôve paired with peers for knowledge-sharing and productivity. And I‚Äôve been the senior dev.
He goes on to say that it‚Äôs easy to put a pairing session on rails to avoid embarrassment, but:
When I think back, my favorite pair-programming sessions were the one where things went wrong. These were the moments that taught me what being a programmer is all about. What do you do when you don‚Äôt know what to do? How do you break down a new problem? What tools do you reach for? When do you abandon your current approach? These are things you can‚Äôt learn from a blog post.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: The best part of pair programming is when things go wrong

SQL should be the first option considered for new data engineering work. It‚Äôs robust, fast, future-proof and testable. With a bit of care, it‚Äôs clear and readable. A new SQL engine - DuckDB - makes SQL competitive with other high performance dataframe libraries, making SQL a good candidate for data of all sizes.
You can make a similar argument for SQL that Gary Bernhardt made for Vim. Here‚Äôs Gary on Vim, run your own s/Vim/SQL/g filter on this as you read it:
‚Ä¶just for me, 15 years; at the beginning of that time, TextMate was just becoming popular. Then it was Sublime Text was cool. Then Atom was cool. Then VS Code was cool. A lot of people switched between two of those, three of those, maybe all four of those, and that whole time I was just getting better and better and better at Vim‚Ä¶ And you multiply that out by the length of a career, you use Vim for 40 years - you‚Äôre gonna be so good at it by the end, and it‚Äôs still gonna be totally relevant, I think.

Chip Huyen:
When we actively hire, our startup gets 150 - 200 applications each month. I read every single one of them. Sometimes, I‚Äôd talk to a candidate and see that what we perceived as their strongest aspects actually weren‚Äôt included in their resume. Occasionally, a candidate would tell me that they didn‚Äôt expect their resume to still be screened by humans ‚Äì had they known, they would have written their resume differently.
The resume evaluation process is pretty much a black box for most candidates. And it is so because few hiring managers have publicly discussed this. I thought I should start the conversation.
Chip‚Äôs team mostly hires for infra and ML roles, so some of the advice here will be catered towards those positions. Still, if you‚Äôre on the job market you‚Äôd be well-served by spending 15-20 minutes reading this post and tweaking your resume where applicable.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: What we look for in a resume

articles.description:
I‚Äôm currently working at a top tier investment bank as a software engineer. I‚Äôm an insignificant cog in a machine that skims the cream from the milk. I‚Äôm earning the most money I‚Äôve ever made and yet I‚Äôm the least fulfilled I‚Äôve ever been.
Right now in the UK and across the world, things are uncertain. Companies are laying workers off, there‚Äôs a cost of living and energy crisis. I‚Äôm excruciatingly lucky to have been in the right place at the right time to develop the skillset I‚Äôve got. In times like these every signal is telling me to stay on the path I‚Äôm on, enjoying the comfort and safety of a high paying job.
I‚Äôm not going to listen. I‚Äôm quitting and I‚Äôm leaving this place. I‚Äôll see you in the mountains.
After this post blew up, Se√°n wrote a follow-up on what quitting the rat race means to him.

articles.description:
Yup, that Neon. Congrats to Nikita and team for this big win.
Databases and web apps go together like peanut butter and jelly. In a word, they‚Äôre inseparable. And despite all the amazing innovations in NoSQL data stores, often a good old relational database is the most reliable tool for the job.
We want to make it completely seamless to develop applications that need databases on Replit. Starting today, you can create and instantly begin to use PostgreSQL databases from within the Replit workspace.
The fine print.
Under the hood, this product is powered by our friends at Neon who have created a lightning-fast serverless database. The database will go to sleep after 5 minutes of inactivity. Most clients should handle the reconnection seamlessly.

imagine "a scenic landscape" "a photo of a dog" "photo of a fruit bowl" "portrait photo of a freckled woman"

Then they are edited (bottom) with the following commands:
>> aimg edit scenic_landscape.jpg "make it winter" --prompt-strength 20
>> aimg edit dog.jpg "make the dog red" --prompt-strength 5
>> aimg edit bowl_of_fruit.jpg "replace the fruit with strawberries"
>> aimg edit freckled_woman.jpg "make her a cyborg" --prompt-strength 13

articles.description:
This project is from the SQLite team themselves. Their reasoning for it:
SQLite is sometimes used as the core of a client/server database system. While it works reliably well in such cases, the database backend module that it uses to store b-tree structures in its database file was not designed with this case in mind and can be improved upon in several ways. The HC-tree (hctree) project is an attempt to develop a new database backend that improves upon regular SQLite as follows‚Ä¶
It improves concurrency, adds support for replication & removes database size limitations.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: An experimental high-concurrency backend for SQLite

articles.description:
Alex Ewerl√∂f and his team implemented ‚ÄúTech Debt Friday‚Äù
Engineers looked forward to the Tech Debt Friday. The team would happily remind management that this day cannot (under any circumstances) be planned for regular feature/bugfix work. Although we fixed some bugs along the way, this was primarily an investment to make future feature development cheaper while improving the maintainability and reliability.
Initially it was hard to defend spending 10% of the team bandwidth on tech debt, but over time the payback was huge
He goes on to list eight things that happened as result of this policy. Good stuff.

Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: What happened when we invested 10% to pay back tech debt

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
If you are the technical co-founder or early engineering lead at a startup, and you want to talk about your microservices, hand-rolled CI/CD, in-house monitoring stack, or any other unique part of your stack, I will say: Cool. Let‚Äôs riff. Take me deep, I‚Äôm ready.
But there‚Äôs something I‚Äôm likely to tell you in return, something I‚Äôll probably insist you‚Äôre overlooking and need to internalize as soon as possible: Your technology stack is not the product.
It‚Äôs easy to get too focused on our tech and tools. Sometimes we think it‚Äôs our competitive advantage, other times it‚Äôs merely personal fascination and intellectual stimulation. This post is a good reminder:
A mindset of technology being the means, not the end, is uncomfortable. But it will help you stay focused on what matters most (the product and your customers), avoid wasteful misadventures, and maximize the company‚Äôs chance of success.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Your tech stack is not the product

articles.author: Jerod Santo
articles.description:
Cedric Chin, writing about the famous adage that says ‚Äúwhen a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.‚Äù
At some level, this is self-evident. Goodhart‚Äôs Law is about as pithy and about as practicable as ‚Äúthe only certainty in life is death and taxes‚Äù and ‚Äúhell is other people.‚Äù It is descriptive; it tells you of the existence of a phenomenon, but it doesn‚Äôt tell you what to do about it or how to solve it.
There are more useful formulations of the law that help solve it. Some organizations use this narrower, more actionable form:
When people are pressured to meet a target value there are three ways they can proceed:
They can work to improve the system
They can distort the system
Or they can distort the data
With that framing in hand, Cedric goes on to describe how you can solve for these three ways and design incentive/measurement systems that work.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Goodhart's Law isn't as useful as you might think
